title: Data Science Help Desk
description:
Visit our virtual data science help desk! 

Introducing the virtual DSI Help Desk, a place to ask your general questions about data science including how to download software or code packages, prep for upcoming DSI classes, get started with programming, connect with data science expertise, and more. No appointments required, just drop in starting January 2023.

How does the DSI Help Desk work?

At the DSI Help Desk, we can answer general data science questions and connect you with a wealth of data science resources and expertise. The Help Desk is hosted by graduate student TAs of the DSI Team twice a week on Tuesdays and Wednesdays from 2-3 pm subject to change to fit the needs of the UCSF community. Due to current COVID-19 guidelines, the Help Desk will be hosted on Zoom, but in-person DSI Help Desk services at Mission Bay/Parnassus campuses may take place in the future. The DSI Help Desk is open to the UCSF community including faculty, staff, and trainees.

We look forward to meeting you (virtually) at the DSI Help Desk in 2023!

 

Access Help Desk: Zoom Link

title: R for Statistics Part 8
description:
This is a part of DSI's SummeR of LeaRning Series.

 

R for Statistics

  • Friday, June 30th, 11:05 AM - 12:00 PM

  • Friday, July 7th, 11:05 AM - 12:00 PM

  • Friday, July 14th, 11:05 AM - 12:00 PM

  • Friday, July 21st, 11:05 AM - 12:00 PM

  • Friday, July 28th, 11:05 AM - 12:00 PM

  • Friday, August 4th, 11:05 AM - 12:00 PM

  • Friday, August 11th, 11:05 AM - 12:00 PM

  • Friday, August 18th, 11:05 AM - 12:00 PM

 

Learn to apply practical statistics in R. We'll cover:

  • Descriptive Statistics

  • Confidence Intervals

  • Hypothesis Testing

  • Regression

  • ANOVA

Beyond applying these statistical techniques, we'll also cover ways to create data visualizations that communicate results.

 

Instructor

Albert Lee is an Instructional Designer and Analyst for the Data Science Initiative at the UCSF Library.

location.name: Mission Bay FAMRI Library: Room CC150 (main reading room)

title: 3D Printing Part 1: Intro to 3D Printing
description:
Are you curious about the applications for 3D printing at UCSF?

Join Makers Lab staff for the first pop-up in a three-part series covering the basics of 3D printing and how the technology can be used in the health sciences.  

After attending the 60-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. List the main components of a 3D printer
  2. Identify four methods for obtaining 3D models
  3. Recognize which is the ideal 3D printer for your project
  4. Generate a print time estimate for a given 3D model
  5. Execute a 3D print from start to finish

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: 3D Printing Part 2: Intro to 3D Modeling
description:
Recommended prerequisite: 3D Printing Part 1

Want to create your own models to 3D print in the Makers Lab?

Join Makers Lab staff for the second pop-up in a three-part series covering the basics of 3D design & modeling using the web-based application Tinkercad. This pop-up is for beginners, but all skills levels are welcome to attend.

After attending the 90-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Design a basic 3D model in Tinkercad
  2. Export a model out of Tinkercad for 3D printing
  3. Locate resources for continuing your learning with Tinkercad
  4. Identify other 3D design & modeling software for more advanced projects

Make sure to sign up for a Tinkercad account before the pop-up and use a three-button if you have one available. You don't even need to download Tinkercad, it is a free, web-based application that you can use anywhere, as long as you have an internet connection.

Need to design 3D models with more complex geometries? Attend an upcoming Fusion 360 pop-up! Unsure if Tinkercad is the right software for your project? Contact Makers Lab staff for suggestions.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Needlecraft Monthly Meet-Up
description:
Calling all fans of knitting, crochet, cross-stitch, sewing, and embroidery!

This virtual meet-up is a chance for beginning and experienced UCSF crafters to come together and work on their projects in a fun and relaxed atmosphere. We hang, we chat, we work on fabulous projects, and share advice and inspiration. Join us!

title: Vector Art for 3D Printing
description:
Recommended prerequisite: Intro to Vector Art, 3D Printing Part 2: Intro to 3D Modeling

Convert 2D vector images into 3D models, no 3D modeling experience required!

Discover how you can convert 2D vector images into printable 3D models in this second installment of our "Intro to Vector Art" series. We will be revisiting Inkscape, a free and open-source vector graphics software, and utilizing its tools to create SVGs that can then be imported into existing 3D designs.

After attending this 60-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  • Identify applications for 3D printing using vector graphics
  • Learn how to simplify profiles for 3D printing using common vector design tools
  • Export SVGs into Tinkercad for 3D printing/modeling

What you will need: Download the latest version of the Inkscape software, available for free for Mac and PC. Sign up for a free Tinkercad account before the pop-up. A three-button mouse is recommended, but not required.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Intro to Python Part 1
description:
This workshop will provide an introduction to programming in Python for people with little or no previous programming experience. We will cover basic variable assignment, loops, conditionals, lists, and functions. Exercises will be hands on and use the Jupyter notebook environment.

For more information, including setup and software requirements, please see the course page at:

https://courses.ucsf.edu/course/view.php?id=5281

Note: This workshop will be offered online through UCSF Zoom. You will recieve an email from libcal with a link prior to the start of the workshop.

title: 3D Printing Part 3: 3D Printing from Medical Imaging
description:
Recommended prerequisite: 3D Printing at UCSF Part 1

Do you have a CT scan you would like to convert to a 3D print?

Join Makers Lab staff to start creating 3D printable models from CT scans. Note: this pop-up will focus on converting and 3D printing models of bone. Learn how 3D printing is helping to improve medical education, research, and patient education.

We encourage attendees to use their own laptops and download the 3D Slicer software prior to the pop-up, available for free for Mac and Windows. A three-button mouse is recommended, but not required. De-identified DICOM files (CT scan) will be provided at the start of the pop-up.

After attending the 90-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Segment bone from a CT scan using a free medical image viewer
  2. Create a 3D surface rendering from a CT scan
  3. Prepare an STL file for 3D printing

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Using the Vivli Data Repository to Share Your Clinical Research Data
description:
Please join us for a webinar about how UCSF researchers can use the Vivli clinical data repository to meet the NIH Data Management and Sharing policy and share their clinical research data. UCSF is now an institutional member of Vivli (meaning you can share your data for free!) and this webinar is designed to help our researchers get up to speed with this platform. Hear from Vivli staff as they give an overview of the repository and share their experiences supporting researchers with their NIH Data Management and Sharing Plans (DMSP).

 

During this webinar, the team from Vivli will:

  • Provide an overview of Vivli, including what types of data should be shared in Vivli
  • Describe the process to share clinical data on Vivli
  • Discuss the benefits of using Vivli to meet the data sharing requirements of your NIH grant

 

Brought to you by the UCSF Library and Clinical & Translational Science Institute (CTSI)

title: Ideation Drawing Part 2
description:
Recommended prerequisite: Ideation Part 1

Following Ideation Part 1, this pop-up dives deeper into refining your visual communication skills. We will briefly recap Ideation 1, and move forward with learning how to use markers for shading. We will explore how to make new shapes and try different techniques to make your drawings more realistic.

After attending the 60-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Draw in perspective without guides
  2. Understand the rules of shading
  3. Use markers for shading
  4. Combine shapes

Since this pop-up will be held on Zoom, we are unable to provide supplies. The materials you will need are a straight-edge, a pencil or ball-point pen, some paper (letter size, any kind), one small or fine tip black marker, and ideally 2 shades of grey markers (or shades of any single color, e.g. dark blue and light blue). 

If you prefer investing in a good set of grey-scale markers with 1 black marker you can check out the recommended set of Prismacolor Cool Grey 12-Count. More affordable marker options (not tested by Makers Lab staff) - Shuttle Art Grey Tones. Grey marker sets can also be found at Dick Blick or Utrecht throughout the Bay Area and online.

To facilitate the learning experience, you are encouraged to share your work during the session.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, please contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Intro to Python Part 2
description:
This workshop is designed to be a follow up course to Introduction to Python, Part 1.  Participants will build on core programming skills and learn to use common Python libraries for data analysis including Pandas for tabular data analysis and matplotlib for graphing and plotting, 

For more information, including please see the CLE course page at: https://courses.ucsf.edu/course/view.php?id=5296

Note: This workshop will be offered online over UCSF Zoom. You will receive a link from libcal prior to the start of the workshop.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment. All pop-ups are currently offered via Zoom.

title: Needlecraft Monthly Meet-Up
description:
Calling all fans of knitting, crochet, cross-stitch, sewing, and embroidery!

This virtual meet-up is a chance for beginning and experienced UCSF crafters to come together and work on their projects in a fun and relaxed atmosphere. We hang, we chat, we work on fabulous projects, and share advice and inspiration. Join us!

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. See all upcoming Needlecraft Meet-Ups to save your seat today!

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, please contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

Photo from meetup attendee and UCSF staff member Brenda

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment. All pop-ups are currently offered via Zoom.
